content: I've added the tag "Primes".

I made a small grammar correction in the line beginning "For example", as someone else had suggested

Otherwise, I think this looks very good

I went ahead and wrote out a quick solution; I think it turned out a little easier than I was anticipating
You can figure out each mapping independently by just finding two primes that have the same power on each side of each clue
I suppose that if this weren't the case, then you would have non-unique solutions, but at first I was expecting to have to come up with something more clever

I do really like how you bound the prime factors, since it shifts the focus of the problem away from writing a super efficient prime factorisation
I'm not sure what is meant by the test cases names: "Index Deduction" and "Iterative Index Deduction". Can you explain this?

Probable defect: in case 9 (test Iterative Index Deduction), the factors in the third clue are:

2860866142560: 2 2 2 2 2 3 3 3 5 17 19 19 29 61 61
78604642094119757: 7 11 11 19 19 29 31 31 37 61 61 67

Sums of power terms don't match. (Neither do distinct prime counts.) I'll admit the problem wording is evasive, but in my interpretation of the problem, that's at odds with the fact the transformation maps a prime to a prime. Or with the way the transformation extends from primes to composites (the specification's an example, I thought I got it but how to be sure?) Or something else that eluded me.

Oh, and I hate you (in a respectful way): the clues are nonobvious enough I'm going to have to switch languages to keep it reasonable. Which is good for a community puzzle, but I wouldn't have wanted that to happen to me in clash context.
The Pi constraint ought to have been a hint, but it's too late for me to have caught it. G'night all.

Oh, I remember this one! (I thought it had been approved long ago) Glad to see it surface in the community puzzles!

Would the word "injective" help the first paragraph after the example? I know it would help *me* more than the sentence in parentheses, but I'm not generalizable.
Come to read it again, I can't deduce the parenthesis from previous; it probably shouldn't be in parentheses at all.

Cosmetics:
- capital Line in input section?
- different color for Pi than Ai/Bi in constraints section?
- naming the number of clues C makes it (crazy) mildly confusable with Ai and Bi (to a retard).
- [english native bait] needs relative pronoun in sentence that starts with "For example"?

Opinion: I'd like the arrows better in Unicode.

Solution: not attempted yet, I'll let you know.
Why not a puzzle instead of a CoC?
The factorisation should use × instead of + (in the 2nd line) :-)
I think it is more difficult like a good portion of the regular puzzles. And i think we need more difficult problems in the coding clashes. (upvote)
I can't make any sense out of the last 2 test cases. I get different amounts of factors for the corresponding numbers in a clue, which i think should not be possible with a mapping like described?
Pretty nice, but I think it should be coffee not reflection. Some people would do pretty nice even in flash.

Yes, maybe, but some people only.
I think that I can brute-force it but the last test won’t pass.
Which pairs do you think are badly matched?
that disturbed me aswell
I submitted this quite a while ago when puzzles weren't a thing

The problem is still there...

I see no valid transformation that maps 2860866142560 to 78604642094119757.


And now, the puzzle has been approved, but cannot be solved. :O
I know, this message was for the super-moderators. ;-)
If you wish, we can move it.
Yeah, probably a good idea
Hmm, I see what you mean, well spotted. I'll try and rework them.
Nice
The last two should pass to brute force, the primes aren't that big.

Brute force with such permutations? I don’t think so. ;-)
I’ll try.
Okay if you mean trying every single permutation of prime sets of varying length then yes, that is not going to work.
